course.subject: COMP
course.name: Python Programming Bridging Course
course.description: This course introduces the Python programming language. It is intended for students who already have some experience in computer programming but wish to learn how to apply those programming skills to the Python language. The course covers basic programming topics, such as variables, functions and loops, to more advanced topics. Students explore these by self-learning of course materials together with guided programming exercises. Students without the prerequisites but possess relevant programming knowledge may seek instructor's approval for enrolling in the course. Graded P or F.
course.prerequisites: COMP 1022P OR COMP 1022Q (prior to 2020-21) OR ISOM 3230 OR ISOM 3320

reviews.author: Canyou
reviews.title: Simple Understanding in Python
reviews.comment_content:
Lesson 1 Introduction to Python
Lesson 1.1 Introduction
Lesson 1.2 Variables
Lesson 1.3 Strings and Lists
Lesson 1.4 Booleans
Lesson 2 Essential Programming in Python
Lesson 2.1 Functions and Making Decisions
Lesson 2.2 Variable Scope
Lesson 2.3 For Loops
Lesson 2.4 While Loops
Lesson 3 2D Arrays and the Game of Life
Lesson 3.1 Two Dimensional Arrays
Lesson 3.2 Conway's Game of Life
Lesson 3.3 Print, Clear Screen and Delay
Lesson 4 Advanced Features
Lesson 4.1 Dictionaries
Lesson 4.2 User Input and Dealing with Errors
Lesson 4.3 File IO
Lesson 5 Recursion and Object-Oriented Programming
Lesson 5.1 Recursion
Lesson 5.2 Turtle Graphics
Lesson 5.3 Drawing Trees
Lesson 5.4 Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming
reviews.comment_teaching:
Self-learning
Actually, if you study all the material, you can pass.
There are some exercises or questions will ask you after the materials. If you do all the materials, passing the course is not a problem. Overall, there is no teaching and it just depends on you. However, if you want to study python from this course, it will be hash when you have too many things to do or study another course in winter.
Also, you just learn the simple and basic overview in this course so it may not be suitable for people who want to study python deeply. Maybe the regular 3 credits course will suit for you.
reviews.comment_grading:
To pass the course, you need to:

1. Submit at least three exercises and achieve 60% out of 100% of the four exercises altogether
2. Get at least 40% in the final exam at the end of the semester
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not too much but some exercises are actually used up lots of time. If you want to study this course, you need to keep your time free. If you study it with other courses or you have other things need to do, you may have difficulties to chase your time.

reviews.author: Yellow
reviews.title: Easy for beginner
reviews.comment_content: All the lecture notes are offered online, no attendance is needed. The content is easy to follow for beginner. There is only one final exam and a few assignments. The instructor would offer some  codes for you to finish the assignment, you don't really need to write down a big paragraph of codes to do the assignment. It is more like filling the blank. And the exam questions are only MC and filling the blank questions.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is a self-learning course, all the learning are done online, but the lecture notes given by the instructor is complete and useful. I only meet the instructor until the final exam..haha..
reviews.comment_grading: This course is pass or  fail course, so the grading is actually not that bad unless you get a F...Unless you didn't read the lecture notes, it is hard to fail the course.
reviews.comment_workload: As it is a one credit course, the workload is acceptable. For a beginner without any knowledge in python, it might still need time to digest the course material in order to finish the assignment by yourself. In general, the workload is okay for 1 credit course.

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.comment_content:
A nice introduction to Python. Since Python is dynamically typed, compared to languages like Java and C++, Python is generally more liberal and easier to write. Thus IMHO transitioning from Java/C++ to Python is, in general, easier than vice versa.

Topics included:
1ï¸âƒ£ Introduction to Python
      ğŸ”¶ Introduction
      ğŸ”¶ Variables
      ğŸ”¶ Strings and Lists
      ğŸ”¶ Booleans
2ï¸âƒ£ Essential Programming in Python
      ğŸ”¶ Functions and Making Decisions
      ğŸ”¶ Variable Scope
      ğŸ”¶ For Loops
      ğŸ”¶ While Loops
3ï¸âƒ£ 2D Arrays and the Game of Life
      ğŸ”¶ Two Dimensional Arrays
      ğŸ”¶ Conway's Game of Life
      ğŸ”¶ Print, Clear Screen and Delay
4ï¸âƒ£ Advanced Features
      ğŸ”¶ Dictionaries
      ğŸ”¶ User Input and Dealing with Errors
      ğŸ”¶ File IOs
5ï¸âƒ£ Recursion and Object-Oriented Programming
      ğŸ”¶ Recursion
      ğŸ”¶ Turtle Graphics
      ğŸ”¶ Drawing Trees
      ğŸ”¶ Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming

The unique features of Python include data structures like lists and dictionaries, and also the way to subset strings and lists using slicing notations. Some elements of Python such as tuples, sets, and lambda functions are not covered, but this is acceptable for an introductory bridging course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Just like other COMP1029 bridging courses, there are no face-to-face lectures and all materials are offered online. The content is well structured and clearly delivered, so you should find no problem understanding the course content.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pass or fail.

Need to get above 60% overall in the assignments (by finishing at least 3 out of 4 of them) and 40% in the final exam. These should be a piece of cake as soon as you pay attention to the deadlines and revise for the exam.
reviews.comment_workload: 4 petty assignments and a final exam. Skeleton codes are provided in the assignments and our work was just to fill in a few lines of code. These should be easy jobs for most of us.

reviews.author: Shujian
reviews.comment_content:
This course provides basic knowledge of Python:
Lesson 1.1 - Getting Started with Python
Lesson 1.2 - Variables
Lesson 1.3 - Strings and Lists
Lesson 1.4 Booleans

Lesson 2.1 - Functions and Making Decisions
Lesson 2.2 - Variable Scope
Lesson 2.3 - For Loops
Lesson 2.4 - While Loops

Lesson 3.1 - Two Dimensional Arrays
Lesson 3.2 - Conway's Game of Life
Lesson 3.3 - Print, Clear Screen and Delay

Lesson 4.1 - Dictionaries
Lesson 4.2 - User Input and Dealing with Errors
Lesson 4.3 - File I/O

Lesson 5.1 - Recursion
Lesson 5.2 - Turtle Graphics
Lesson 5.3 - Drawing Trees
Lesson 5.4 - Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming
reviews.comment_teaching: No lectures, all materials are on the course Canvas page for your self reading.
reviews.comment_grading:
P/F
4 programming exercise, online, 25% each, get 60%+ to pass
final exam, f2f, get 40%+ to pass
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. There are four programming exercise. Skeleton code is provided for each exercise, and there are detailed comments telling you how to write the code. If you want, you can finish all 4 exercises in 1 hour.

reviews.author: Anacreon
reviews.title: Do NOT trust the sample final !!!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic python.

Introduction to Python
Essential Programming in Python
2D Arrays and the Game of Life
Advanced Features
Recursion and Object-Oriented Programming
reviews.comment_teaching:
Just reading. Google is more useful.
Do more yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mysterious.
This 1 credit course, according to its final exam, seems to require we put in a similar amount of effort as the 1021 3 credit course.
Mean of the final exam was 59.7/100 this semester.
reviews.comment_workload:
The sample final is ridiculously simple compared with the online final I took. DO NOT TRUST THAT!!!
20 questions 1 hour, 3 min for one, haha. It reminded me of the JAVA, 1022p final. The questions the codes are longer than the sample. The sample only has 13 questions and it is much simpler than the online final. I trusted it and I didn't be that careful while reviewing.
If you prepared this final as I did, then it is quite easy to GG.

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: Good Filler Course in the Summer Holiday
reviews.comment_content:
Course contents are given in 5 weeks:
*Lesson 1: Basic Python syntax, variables, strings, lists, boolean operators
*Lesson 2: Function writing, variable scope, for and while loops
*Lesson 3: 2D arrays, print and clear screen, delay function
*Lesson 4: Dictionaries, user input, try-except-else, file I/O
*Lesson 5: Recursion and turtle graphics

When compared with what is taught in COMP1021 (the regular Python introductory course), I think COMP1029P retains most of the contents of COMP1021.

As most Python learners will tell you, Python is actually quite easy to learn. (Professing it is another issue tho) When comparing the difficulties of learning Java in COMP1022P as a newbie at that time (in which I took in Fall Sem in 2021), Python is really much much easier...

And as usual with other programming classes, practice helps, especially considering the fact that COMP1029P is a self-learning course. In general, the course is quite a nice filler course for the long holidays to keep your brain running.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Same as what you've seen on the class schedule and others said, this is a self-learning course. Course contents are given on a weekly basis (and you can't access future contents). The emails of both Professor Lam and the TA (Peter Chung) is given for students to ask questions.

Professor Lam gives helpful responses regarding courses, and this even extends to some more out-of-scope contents: for example, he responded to my question why Python file I/O don't work for Microsoft Word--on Sunday, which I didn't expect.

On the other hand, when I asked for a technical problem on one of my assignment, Peter Chung insisted that my code is wrong, and his responses only increased my confusion instead of clarifying my question. What's next? I still get full marks for that assignment the next day.

That said, as I only have 2 occasions to contact the professor and TA with email, my opinions here may not be too representative.
reviews.comment_grading:
Like other COMP1029* courses, COMP1029P adopts the pass-fail mechanism. You get a pass if you get more than 60% for the mean of all assignments, and 40% for the final exam. For me, I get full mark for all assignments, and scored of 75/100 for the final exam.

The professor also claimed that there should be enough easy questions in the exam, which is true per my experience. At the end at least one guy failed miserably (?*2) at a score of 38 for the exam, showing even those who performed bad in programming may even have a chance to pass this course.

While meaningless to a course which don't pull the curve, most of the homeworks have a mean of over 80%, and the exam's mean is 76.92/100.
reviews.comment_workload:
In general, nearly zero workload (though more workload than spam courses like PHYS1003).

There are a total of 4 assignments since week 2, and you are given with a week to deal with each of them. In fact, they are so easy that I can finish all of them within 2 to 3 days after the assignment is released.

There will also be 2-3 review questions per week, designed to encourage practicing the course content. While all of them won't count towards the final grade (?), review questions for week 2 is a component part of the week's assignment.

reviews.author: chickenwing
reviews.comment_content: The course covers basic programming topics, such as variables, functions and loops, to more advanced topics. Students explore these by self-learning of course materials together with guided programming exercises. Students without the prerequisites but possess relevant programming knowledge may seek instructor's approval for enrolling in the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: the lecture notes given by the instructor is complete and useful. and the instructor tried to explained the questions we proposed as mu as possible
reviews.comment_grading: This course is pass or  fail course, so the grading is actually not that bad if you treat this course seriously
reviews.comment_workload: workload is acceptable. For a beginner without any knowledge in python, it might still need time to digest the course material in order to finish the assignment by yourself.

reviews.author: saote
reviews.comment_content: some elementary syntax about python. also introduce some more advanced features(OOP/recursion) in the last part of the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: it's based on a self-learning website. nothing much to comment about.
reviews.comment_grading:
it's a P/F course.
need to get at least 60% out of 100% of the assignments and 40% of the final exam to pass.
I feel like if you do understand the content, it's easy to pass.
reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is adequate for a 1-cre course.
There's an easy assignment once a week and a total of four of them. simply follow the web instruction and it should be done in one or two hours.

reviews.author: Ivylo
reviews.title: Interesting Python beginner course
reviews.comment_content: A introductory course for students who are interested in Python as Python is getting popular in the computer world, especially for Deep Learning development. However, this course is way from sufficient for those keep learners. But considering the short duration, amount of content is acceptable.
reviews.comment_teaching: Though videos are already available for demonstration, especially those assignments, it will be even better if videos are also available in course content given the current teaching method is almost texts, making it a bit boring and not friendly to beginners.
reviews.comment_grading:
A course with only Pass or Fail.

To pass COMP1029P, you have to fulfil following requirements:
1. on average, 60% or higher of the 4 exercises total mark (at least to submit 3 exercises)
2. 40% or higher in the final exam
reviews.comment_workload: 4 lab exercises in total with 1 final exam within the one month duration in Winter semester.

reviews.author: çç å¥¶éœ¸
reviews.comment_content:
not too many. it is easy for the programming beginners.
there are only 4/5 lectures chapter
reviews.comment_teaching: it is a self-learning course and the teaching materials are good. it is easy to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
it is easy to pass, you need to get 40% in exam and 60% in homework.
in my exam, mostly asking you about the output and there are some MC also 1-2 question asked you to write the program.
reviews.comment_workload: only have 5 homework in the total semester. Each homework has a teaching video, and you can follow the video to type the program.

reviews.author: MEMENTO
reviews.comment_content: The content includes basic data type, arrays and dictionaries, for loop and while loop, input and output handling and basic recursion.
reviews.comment_teaching: This is an online course, which means that there is no lecture. You need to learn by yourself by reading though the course material in the CSE website.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is pass or fail course.
To pass one of these bridging courses, you need to:
obtain 60% or higher of the four exercises total mark, and:
obtain 40% or higher in the final exam
It is extremely easy to get over 40% of grade in the final, so you do not have to worry at all.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is very light. There are four exercises in total, and each takes less than an hour to complete. You only need to complete one exercise every 2-3 weeks.
